messages.message: Does anyone have an example of a Refiner + Flow that requires an Instabase Auth Token to be passed into some functions in the Refiner program? Wondering what our best practices are for this
Oh, instabase auth token shouldn’t be propagated to the refiner programs.  If it is being required, then it might be an abstraction leak problem which we should fix.

I was told the exact opposite I believe? Context: model service can be interacted with via GRPC or API endpoint. API endpoint uses Auth and correctly obtains the username - with GRPC, I can pass in any username since our platform doesnt have proper authentication for file service (we just pass in the username), so I was told it is better for the user to pass in an auth token. cc @Heymian
happy to elaborate more if this doesnt make sense

Ideally what we would want is for file service to stop using username as its approach to auth, use an auth token instead, and have a special UDF variable that provides an auth token that can be used in the UDF to call into these services.
hmm, may be we should chat a bit about this in more detail
Yes definitely - this is something that should change and will make UDF security a lot better, but will also likely be a big change. Maybe a few of us can schedule a call this week?
I can put it on the calendar - anyone else that should be added?
I think my context was the way that customers can call APIs directly from UDF (e.g. the database APIs) and the API token is in the udf itself.
But wouldn’t that require the user calling it and their auth token?
Because if the auth token is hardcoded, how does that get sent to a customer?
(in the meantime, @Heymian do you know where example of that may be?)
currently yes, it’s hardcoded, we should ideally be able to send it through though.
